III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS & CONCLUSIONS
A. Physical Description of Facility
The facility is a one-story structure located in a rural area outside the city of Kalamazoo.
When you turn off the street, the facility is located after a long winding driveway. Upon
entering the facility, there is a group counseling room to the right and straight ahead a
large reception area. Within this reception area is a small area designated for small
groups. To the left of this area is the Dining/recreation area with a counter, sink, and
refrigerator. Continuing straight ahead, you enter an area designed for television
watching and gaming by the youth. Just to the left of this area are two bathrooms and
“hygiene sinks”. Turning left and walking down a hallway, you enter the area designated
for youth sleeping rooms, laundry room, therapy room, storage rooms, and a staff office.
The first door on the left in the hallway is a therapy room followed by the laundry room
on the left also. Within the laundry room is a secondary room that holds the medication

for youth along with their personal items they enter the program with. Both the laundry
room and medication/personal items room are locked, and no youth are allowed in
these two areas. Further down the hall the next room on the left is an “’isolation room”
that will be used for youth that are sick. This room has a bathroom attached. Next to this
room is a bathroom on the left. Across the hall and to the right are two youth sleeping
rooms. Each room is 1,475 square feet which allows for two youth to sleep in the rooms.
Each room is set up with beds and dressers, along with closet space for the youth’s
items. Further down the hall and next to the first two sleeping rooms on the right is a
bathroom for the youth. Following this bathroom are two more sleeping rooms both of
which are 1,475 square feet. The facility will be licensed to handle fourteen youth and
there is appropriate sleeping rooms for all fourteen. Across the hall from the bathroom is
a room for storage followed by three more 1,475 square foot bedrooms. The last room
in the hallway is a staff office. Each room has windows and the sleeping room’s
windows do not open. If you turned right after entering the facility, you will pass a
conference room on the right and a “unit supervisor room” on the left. Going down this
hall, the next room on the right is the locked mechanical room followed by a large
supervisor office. Across the hall from these two rooms and on the left of the hallway is
the pantry and commercial kitchen. Following the kitchen on the left is another
mechanical room followed by a staff break room. Across the hall and to the right of the
hall are four office spaces to be used by staff. Crossing a perpendicular hallway, you
enter a large “Recreation room” with several storage closets on the left. This recreation
room is 14,555 square feet. Turing left when you enter the perpendicular hallway and
following the hallway you come to a ninety degree turn to the right and on the left is the
training room. Following this room is the “flex office room”. Across the hallway from
these two rooms is the second entrance to the recreation room. Outside of the building
and in the back, is a basketball court and soccer field in a fenced in area. Outside of the
fenced in area is a large, wooded area and no other buildings are in sight. In the front of
the facility is a large parking lot.
B. Program Description
Bethany Christian Services’ Hacienda de Luz (HdL) program is a specialized,
community-based, residential facility, equipped to house single, unaccompanied minors.
The program boasts a therapeutic modality that is able to treat mental health issues and
substance abuse issues simultaneously. Daily programming builds the youths
independent living skills to better prepare them to be successful members of the
community. This program provides an intensive, routine based, structured setting with
qualified, bi-lingual, and culturally competent staff members. The facility has an
immersive English learning program which encourages youth to build their English
language and vocabulary skills on a daily basis. This program will serve an all-male
population (14-Youth) between the ages of 14-17 who are unaccompanied minors, new
to the U.S. Many of these youth offer a unique challenge for treatment due to their
extensive history of abuse, neglect, or abandonment, and subsequent trauma history
during travel to the United States; and may require intensive services in a structured
environment. The home primarily specializes in treating mental health concerns, such
as PTSD, and substance abuse disorders, simultaneously. The program serves youth

who have been screened eligible for community-based living and who are appropriate
for the services provided.
Services provided in this program are described as the following. The youth who are
referred to be placed at Hacienda de Luz come with a variety of needs including
Substance Abuse, Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD), history of parental abuse,
neglect, or abandonment (including human trafficking), lack of education, lack of U.S.
cultural awareness, minimum independent living skills abilities, and various adjustment
disorders that warrant rigorous, thorough, and intensive services. As a result, Hacienda
de Luz has an intensive therapeutic and educationally based skills training program in
order to meet these needs, build upon the strengths of youth serviced, and introduce
new positive skills. It is anticipated that the youth referred to Hacienda de Luz program
will stay in the home until they are either reclassified into the Unaccompanied Refugee
Minors Program and are ready for independent living, or until they are ready for another
appropriate placement. This process usually takes approximately 12 months. Upon
intake, each youth is assigned a bilingual case manager who provides intensive case
management services. The assigned case manager meets with all new youth within 24
hours of intake and then at a minimum of weekly thereafter. In addition, within 30 days
of intake, all incoming youth are assessed to determine what types of behavioral
interventions, and a tailored behavioral plan, will be put in place to ensure a successful
transition into the home, community, and school. Emergency crisis intervention is
available 24/7, with staff directly involved in Bethany Christian Services’ residential
programs, taking shifts to cover emergencies.
The program at Hacienda de Luz is based upon a differentiation of levels and
movement towards the youth’s independence, adjustment, and autonomy from the
home. The Personal Independence Education (PIE) system has youth complete a
variety of learning opportunities to prepare them for Independent Living. Each level, or
“PIE slice,” focuses on an area that is necessary to live independently. Once the youth
masters a PIE slice, they move onto the next, until the PIE is completed, and they
graduate from the program. The PIE slices are identified: Orientation, Culture &
Community, Relationships, Money Management, Home Maintenance, Education &
Employment, Health & Wellness, Personal Development, and Transition Independence.
C. Rule/Statutory Violations
R 400.4543 Doors
Rule 543. (4) Interior doors to any enclosure which is required
to have not less than a 1-hour fire resistance rating shall be B-
labeled fire doors in labeled frames and shall be equipped
with positive-latching hardware and self-closing devices.
The Fire Inspection completed on 10/23/21 resulted in a “C” rating. A variance was
granted to allow the facility to be licensed for the residential portion of the building
that the Qualified Fire Inspector approved for use. The other portion of the building
will not be used by youth until an approved A rating is provided and approved by the
Division of Child Welfare Licensing. The new fire doors have been ordered but will

R 400.4552 Heating devices and flame producing devices.
Rule 552. (1) In large and secure facilities and all newly
constructed and converted facilities, flame-producing-type
heating devices and incinerators shall be in an enclosure
providing at least 1-hour resistance to fire. Adequate
combustion air shall be provided directly from the outside
through a permanently open louver. Fire dampers are not
required in ducts penetrating this enclosure.
The Fire Inspection completed on 10/23/21 resulted in a “C” rating. A variance was
granted to allow the facility to be licensed for the residential portion of the building
that the Qualified Fire Inspector approved for use. The other portion of the building
will not be used by youth until an approved A rating is provided and approved by the
Division of Child Welfare Licensing.
IV. RECOMMENDATION
I recommend issuance of an original six-month license to this child caring
institution, private for the use of the residential portion of the building only. Upon
receipt of an A rating Fire Inspection and approval by Division of Child Welfare
Licensing the facility can use the recreation and training room, along with staff
offices.
